abstract: "There's this inherent tension between privacy and personalization in the digital realm," was how Michael Zimbalist, Vice President for R&D at the New York Times, began the TimesOpen discussion of privacy at personalization he was moderating.We all expect a more personalized experience, but to get them, the entities providing the experience all need to know something about us, Zimbalist pointed out., "There's tension that comes with what they know about us, what we're willing to share with them, and what we get in return."Discussants included Edward Felten, Chief Technologist at the Federal Trade Commission and Princeton computer science professor; Marc Zwillinger, founding partner at the law firm Zwillgen PLLC; Randall Rothenberg, President and CEO of the Internet Advertising Bureau; Colin O'Malley, Chief strategy officer at Evidon, operator of Ghostery; and Duncan Watts, Principal research scientist at Yahoo! Research and author, most recently, of "Everything is Obvious, Once You Know the Answer."
